proof.text: Let there be set out two rational straight lines ,  commensurable in square only and such that the square on , being the greater, is greater than the square on  the less by the square on a straight line commensurable in length with . [elem.10.29]
And let the square on  be equal to the rectangle , .
Now the rectangle ,  is medial; [elem.10.21] therefore the square on  is also medial; therefore  is also medial. [elem.10.21]
Let the rectangle ,  be equal to the square on .
Now the square on  is rational; therefore the rectangle ,  is also rational.

And since, as  is to , so is the rectangle ,  to the square on , while the square on  is equal to the rectangle , , and the rectangle ,  is equal to the square on , therefore, as  is to , so is the square on  to the rectangle , .
But, as the square on  is to the rectangle , , so is  to ; therefore also, as  is to , so is  to .
But  is commensurable with  in square only; therefore  is also commensurable with  in square only. [elem.10.11]
And  is medial; therefore  is also medial. [elem.10.23, addition]

And since, as  is to , so is  to , and the square on  is greater than the square on  by the square on a straight line commensurable with , therefore also the square on  is greater than the square on  by the square on a straight line commensurable with . [elem.10.14]

Therefore two medial straight lines , , commensurable in square only and containing a rational rectangle, have been found, and the square on  is greater than the square on  by the square on a straight line commensurable in length with .

Similarly also it can be proved that the square on  exceeds the square on  by the square on a straight line incommensurable with , when the square on  is greater than the square on  by the square on a straight line incommensurable with . [elem.10.30]
